newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds fall sharply on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds fall sharply on profit-taking.

text.p: Argentine bonds fell sharply Tuesday amid a combination of growing concerns over corruption accusations and profit-taking by U.S. funds after a year of solid gains.
"Investors are looking for excuses to sell," said one trader at a large Argentine bank, referring to the large gains clocked up by emerging markets this year.
The dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 2 due 2001 slumped $0.70 to 117.50, while Argentina's FRB due 2005 plunged 1-5/8 to 80-1/2.
The dollar-denominated Bocon Provisional 2 due 2007 shed $1.50 to 100.30.
Increasing attention on corruption accusations by former Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo, including rumours of the resignation of a cabinet minister, gave investors an excuse, said traders.

The government denied the rumours, which centered on Interior Minister Carlos Corach, Justice Minister Elias Jassan and presidential chief of staff Alberto Kohan. A presidential spokesman told Reuters "it's totally false. There is no movement. There will be no resignations."
However, traders pointed out that the market fell in sympathy with similar downward moves in other Latin American markets.
"There is selling pressure. The market is seeking trading levels where there will be no doubt that buying will emerge," said another trader.
The first trader predicted prices could slip for another couple of sessions. He added that so far there were no large selling flows.
Market players underlined that the market fell in tandem with other Latin American markets, adding weight to the argument that the declines were part of general profit-taking by overseas funds.
In the money markets, call money rates fell to 7.35 percent from 7.55 percent Monday.
